ASCEND.deftext:
to go up, rise, climb

ASCEND means simply to go up.

“The elevator ASCENDED to the top floor.”

“They threw bags of sand out of the balloon to make it ASCEND.”

“The soldier ASCENDED through the ranks until he became a general.”

Many people confuse ASCEND with its opposite descend, which means to go down.

“They ASCENDED the mountain in the morning, and descended it in the afternoon.”

Other forms of the word: ASCENT, n.

OUTLANDISH.deftext:
strange, bizarre, ridiculous

OUTLAND is a rare word for a foreign land or country—a land that is outside your own. Something that it OUTLANDISH has a foreign or unfamiliar appearance or quality. It is strange, bizarre, exotic.

“She dressed in OUTLANDISH clothing just to shock people.”

“He had some OUTLANDISH ideas about flying saucers.”

“They made some OUTLANDISH suggestions about how to improve television.”

UNCANNY.deftext:
weird, strange, mysterious

UNCANNY means weird or strange. The word is applied to people, events, or feelings that are so beyond what is normal or expected that they make you feel frightened or uncomfortable.

“He has an UNCANNY way of knowing what you’re thinking.”

“That dog is so smart it’s almost UNCANNY.”

“We were frightened by the UNCANNY sounds.”

VIVID.deftext:
lively, spirited, intense

VIVID comes from a Latin word meaning to live, also the source of English words like survive and revive. VIVID means “full of life and freshness.” The word is used about things, as well as about ideas, memories, imaginations, and the like.

“The picture is painted in sharp, VIVID colors that make a strong impression on the eye.”

“After all these years her memories of her trip to Europe are still fresh and VIVID.”

“The author wrote a VIVID account of the battle. You almost felt as if you were there.”

“Little Billy has a VIVID imagination. He’s always pretending to be a detective or an astronaut.”

NULLIFY.deftext:
to make void, invalidate, negate The NULL part of the word means nothing. NULL is an adjective which means “without value or effect.” It is often used in the phrase “NULL and void,” which means “having no legal force.”

“The judges declared that the agreement was NULL and void.”

To NULLIFY something is to make it as if it were nothing, to take away its force, value, or usefulness.

“The referee’s decision NULLIFIED the touchdown.”

“His refusal to let us finish NULLIFIED all our work for the past month. It’s as if we’d never even begun.”

Other forms of the word: NULL, adj. NULLIFICATION, n.

INTERSPERSE.deftext:
to scatter, place here and there

To INTERSPERSE things is to scatter or sprinkle them between or among other things.

“Some red balls were INTERSPERSED among the black ones.”

“She INTERSPERSED some very funny jokes in an otherwise serious speech.”

In a slightly different sense, to INTERSPERSE something with other things is to supply it with these things here and there.

“He INTERSPERSED the black balls with some red ones.”

“The book was INTERSPERSED with many beautiful pictures.”

FACSIMILE.deftext:
a copy, reproduction

Note the pronunciation. The final e is sounded.

FACSIMILE is related to the word similar. Both come from a Latin word meaning like. A FACSIMILE is an exact, or almost exact, copy of a book, painting, letter, or the like.

“He printed a FACSIMILE of the Declaration of Independence that was identical in every detail with the original.”

“She wore a dress that was a close FACSIMILE of an expensive Paris design.”

The most common mistake on the Pretest is to choose original as the meaning of FACSIMILE. This is a confusion of a word with its opposite. A FACSIMILE is made from an original, but it is not the original itself.

CONSEQUENCE.deftext:
an effect, result; importance, value

A CONSEQUENCE is the effect or result of something that has gone before.

“His success was a direct CONSEQUENCE of his hard work.” CONSEQUENCE often suggests a bad or undesired result.

“If you steal this, you’ll have to accept the CONSEQUENCES when you are caught.”

“He didn’t consider all the CONSEQUENCES of his thoughtless behavior.”

In a different sense, CONSEQUENCE means importance, particularly with regard to the results that may come about from something.

“His refusal to come was of no CONSEQUENCE. We had a good time anyway.”

“She is a woman of great CONSEQUENCE in her community. Nothing is done without her approval.”

Other forms of the word: CONSEQUENTIAL, adj.

CANINE.deftext:
of or relating to dogs

CANINE means “of or like a dog.”

“A human’s CANINE teeth are pointed, like a dog’s teeth.”

“He followed his older brother around all day with CANINE devotion"—that is, he followed him like a dog following its master. CANINE is also a noun, meaning dog or “member of the dog family.”

“Poodles, collies, and terriers are all CANINES.”

“The fox is the only CANINE that can climb a tree.”

The most popular wrong answer on the Pretest is cat. The word which means “of or like a cat” is feline, not CANINE.

PLACID.deftext:
peaceful, calm, tranquil

PLACID means “free from disturbance,” calm, untroubled.

“Not the slightest ripple disturbed the PLACID surface of the lake.”

When used about people, PLACID means “having a peaceful nature,” and sometimes suggests a person who is too calm and lacking in feeling.

“She was so PLACID that not even the roar of the jet planes bothered her.”

Soft and weak are both sometimes chosen as the meaning of PLACID. They are both close, but not quite the same as peaceful, calm, untroubled. They might be chosen because of a confusion of PLACID with flaccid, which means weak, flabby.

Other forms of the word: PLACIDITY, n.

ELAPSE.deftext:
to pass, slip by, glide by

ELAPSE is almost always used about time. It means simply to pass, to go by.

“Twenty seconds ELAPSED between the two shots"—that is, the shots came twenty seconds apart.

“He returned after six months had ELAPSED.”

ELAPSE should not be confused with the similar verb lapse, which can be used about time, but it is more commonly used to mean “to fall into error” or “to go out of existence.” You can say “The insurance policy lapsed"; it doesn’t make sense, however, to say “The insurance policy ELAPSED.”

UPHOLD.deftext:
to support, approve

UPHOLD is made up of the two words hold and up. UPHOLD means just that: to hold up or support. UPHOLD can be used about physical things like a roof, but it is generally used about ideas, decisions, or beliefs.

“The lower court’s decision in the case was UPHELD by the higher court.”

“He tried to UPHOLD his family’s good reputation.”

“I do not UPHOLD actions which are dangerous to oneself or others.”

Put off is the most frequently marked wrong answer on the Pretest, probably because one meaning of hold up is to delay.

STRICKEN.deftext:
wounded, afflicted, overcome

STRICKEN comes from the word strike. Someone who is STRICKEN with something has been struck or struck down by it. The word is usually used about illness, sorrow, misfortune, or the like.

“She was STRICKEN with a terrible disease.”

“Several soldiers lay STRICKEN on the battlefield.”

“After the flood the Red Cross aided the STRICKEN families.”

Panic-STRICKEN means “overwhelmed with great fear.”

“The panic-STRICKEN people fled from the huge monster.”

STRICKEN is also used in other phrases like conscience-STRICKEN and grief-STRICKEN.

MONOTONOUS.deftext:
unchanging, boring, tedious, repetitious

The mono part of MONOTONOUS comes from the Greek word for one. A monologue is a speech for one person; a monocle is an eyeglass worn in one eye only. The ton part of the word comes from the word tone. Something that is MONOTONOUS has only one tone; it doesn’t vary at all, and therefore it is boring and uninteresting.

“The scenery was rather MONOTONOUS; there was nothing but cornfields as far as you could see.”

“The book was impressive at first, but after a while its heavy style became rather MONOTONOUS.”

“She quickly became bored with the MONOTONOUS work on the assembly line in the factory.”

Other forms of the word: MONOTONY, n.

ELUDE.deftext:
to escape, evade, slip away, avoid

To ELUDE someone is to avoid or evade him, usually by means of cleverness or quickness.

“The criminal managed to ELUDE the police by hiding in the trunk of a car.”

“The halfback ELUDED several tackles with his clever moves.”

Things or ideas can ELUDE you, usually by being very difficult or hard to see.

“The answer ELUDED Bob. No matter how hard he tried he couldn’t quite think of it.”

“The change she made in the room was so small that it ELUDED my notice.”

Other forms of the word: ELUSIVE, adj.

questions.prompt: Do you go higher as you ASCEND?
Would a talking horse be UNCANNY?
Would a VIVID story be dull to read?
Can you INTERSPERSE apples with oranges?
Is a FACSIMILE generally more valuable than an original?
Is going to prison sometimes a CONSEQUENCE of committing a crime?
Is a cocker spaniel a member of the CANINE family?
Do PLACID people get angry easily?
Does it take a hundred years for a century to ELAPSE?
Would most people like their decisions to be UPHELD?
Would a grief-STRICKEN person be unhappy?
Would MONOTONOUS music be fascinating to listen to?
Has a person in prison ELUDED punishment for his crime?
The airplane fell from the sky and ASCENDED to the ground.
Her OUTLANDISH methods of teaching constantly got her into trouble with the principal.
She has an UNCANNY ability to predict the weather.
I have a VIVID picture in my mind of exactly how the room is going to look.
The governor NULLIFIED the contract with the firm because they were cheating the state.
His workday was INTERSPERSED with many chances to relax and regain his strength.
John could produce a reasonably good FACSIMILE of George Washington's signature.
When the automobile was invented, no one realized the CONSEQUENCES it would have on the American way of life.
We call them CANINE teeth because they resemble an elephant's tusks.
She put a nice PLACID pillow beneath his head to make him more comfortable.
They ELAPSED the afternoon with friends on a picnic in the woods.
The heavy rains UPHELD the game for over an hour.
The entire city was STRICKEN with the plague.
She was very MONOTONOUS with the children—always telling them jokes and thinking up games for them to play.
We ELUDED them by escaping through a secret passage.
